Header: Lysins plus antibiotics: a cure for human bacterial infections?
Content: Scientists have found that a protein called lysin extracted from bacteriophage out of areas like New York Cityâ€™s East River could lead to life-saving medicine to combat antibiotic-resistant infections. The drugs have reached the first human trials after decades of research. Health officials warn that the declining efficacy of antibiotics threatens to unleash a post-antibiotic era in which even some minor infections could become fatal. By combining antibiotics with lysin, Dr. Vincent Fischetti, professor at The Rockefeller University in the Laboratory of Bacterial Pathogenesis and Immunology, successfully killed dangerous bacteria such as MRSA in mice.
